item.title: Architecture | Nuno Soares Proposal for Hac-Sá Beach Wins Prize
item.description: “Park of Tides”, a project led by architect Nuno Soares, from the “Urban Pratice” studio, received the Silver Award in the “Landscape Design - Public Landscape” category in the London Design Awards 2024. The proposal, launched in a public tender by invitation by the Institute for Macao Municipal Affairs in early 2024, aimed to “create an accessible pedestrian route that would connect the two ends of the beach, incorporating simultaneously leisure facilities”, describes the statement. "Park of Tides" is inspired "in the natural rhythm of the tides", having an area of ​​12 thousand square meters, where it reinterprets "the route with an expansion in the form of wave". In this proposal, it is foreseen “a modern, green and accessible space by the sea, which values ​​the natural beauty and recreational value of Hac Sá beach”. Nuno Soares also developed three zones, centered on leisure and interactive spaces, exploration of natural materials and outdoor activities and another place with “design and contemporary facilities”. Thus, together, these three zones "reimagine the riverside area as a multifunctional and inclusive destination for visitors to engage, explore and relax." Cited by the same note, Nuno Soares explained that this project “adopts a minimal impact approach, where permeable structures and natural materials are involved with the terrain”, as well as representing a “commitment” of the studio “with sustainable and inclusive architectural practices, ensuring ecological preservation while increasing the well-being of the community”. The London Design Awards, together with the International Awards Associate, recognize projects that are exceptional and creative influence proposing to promote works of designers involved in various fields, bringing recognition those who overcome the industry.

item.title: Housing | Centaline warns that prices will fall up to 20 percent
item.description:
The real estate agency draws a negative scenario of the real estate market, which affects the price of housing, but also the rent of stores. According to the company, after years in denial, the landlords of stores begin to realize that they will lose money
The Centaline Real Estate Agency foresees that housing prices will have a broken 10 to 20 percent throughout the year. The forecast appears in the agency's latest report on the local real estate market, published at the end of last week, and points out that the sector crosses an "ice age." "The Macao real estate market is going through a 'U' form phase of development, so the pressure to reduce housing prices are expected to extend," is mentioned. "Housing prices will cross a new vacancy of breaks between 10 and 20 percent," he was added. By referring to the form of “U”, the centine predicts that the fall is followed by a period of growth after a phase of stagnation. However, it is necessary to reach the bottom. And this moment is difficult to predict: "The dimension of the fall will depend on several factors, including the pace of interest reduction in the United States, as well as market aid policies," he was explained. Based on this trend, the agency admits that a “ice age” is lived: “the real estate market has entered the ice age, with housing prices and the volume of transactions falling,” he was written. "In the second quarter, our estimates point to the volume of transactions of about 200 transactions per month," was planned. Wake up to reality Regarding the store lease market, the situation is not much different, and the Centaline indicates that store owners will have to accept the new reality, and possibly undo the stores. "Last year, many of the investors still believed that the drop in income price was due to the pandemic or increased interest rates. They believed that everything was going back to 'normality', so they preferred to pay interest [of mortgages] and keep the bet on their investments," he was explained. "Recently, they began to realize that the days of good investment in stores have come to an end, the retail sales sector has been transformed and dependence on physical stores has decreased considerably. So the value of stores is gradually decreasing. In holding their investments, they will hardly get good results," he was added. The centine thus draws a scenario at two speeds. In the most central tourism zones, it admits that there were close to 20 leases where the income value was above 100 thousand patacas. However, in community neighborhoods the situation is very different, especially at the level of stores in Nape or Horta and Costa.

item.title: Economic Housing | Permanent candidacy is again removed
item.description:
With attention focused on competitions for economic housing launched and 2019, 2021 and 2023, the Housing Institute removes the hypothesis allow permanent candidates. Regarding the five suspended housing projects in zone A of the new landfills, the government remains without construction plans
The Housing Institute (IH) is concentrated “in the work of appreciation and attribution of applications to Economic Housing of 2019, 2021 and 2023”. As such, it is not being weighted, in the short term, the permanent candidacy for economic housing, since it is necessary to comprehensively consider social changes and other factors, ”said the president of IH, iam Leng Leng, in response to a written interpellation of Nick Law. The deputy linked to the community of Fujian has insisted on the reform of housing policies, in particular in his flexibility. Nick Law stressed that there is no mechanism in the law that allows the exchange of housing fractions, a situation that penalizes individual candidates who cannot change their home even if over the contest marry or have children. Also on the possibility of changing home, I were Leng Leng has not advanced a concrete position, merely answering that the government will optimize housing policies and that it has launched a study on the viability of the economic housing exchange regime. The deputy asked when the study would be completed and if his results will be released, but the president of IH did not respond. Good zone A year ago, the then secretary for transport and public works, Raimundo do Rosario, revealed in the Legislative Assembly that the government would suspend the construction of six residential economic housing complexes in zone A of new landfills, which would add 5,700 apartments to the city's housing park. It should be noted that Raimundo do Rosario revealed the suspension in response to an oral interpellation of Nick Law. A year later, the deputy re -interrogated the government on construction and development projects. The president of the HI replied that, "taking into account the situation of candidacies for economic housing verified in the last two contests, the Government of MSAR, after evaluation, decided to suspend the development of economic housing projects in lots A13, B13, B14, B15 and B16, and there is no new plans for now."

item.title: National Security | Government wants to review laws on associations

item.title: Álvaro Barbosa, vice-rector of the University of São José: “Student visa is very limiting”
item.description:
The University of São José continues the negotiation saga with the Chinese authorities to recruit students from the interior of China. Vice-rector Álvaro Barbosa expects, soon, the increase in master's students from 30 to 200. Regarding the internationalization of higher education, the official advocates changes in student visas to facilitate recruitment
Does the recruitment of students from the interior of China remain a matter pending to the University of Saint Joseph? It is a process that is underway. We have had huge support from the Macao government in negotiations to obtain the quota for our university, and they have been tireless in the effort to try to resolve the issues raised by the central government. Many of the questions are legitimate and concern concerns that arise. We were granted a temporary quota of 30 students for masters ago over a probative period, which served to evaluate how we, as Western University, would host students from China. From China, there is this concern with the host of students in Macau. I think we have made a huge effort and the students who are there, included in this contingent, are quite satisfied. Is this quota for masters just? Yes. For a degree we do not have authorization yet. In this way, we are currently at the time we try to overcome this probative period in order to obtain a quota of about 200 students for masters. We are in the final phase of the evaluation process and everything has been doing well. We will have the possibility that, next academic year, expand this quota. That would be great, because for our university, to have a greater impact of our mission in Macao, it is essential to have access to students from mainland China. We cannot be a university in an integrated region in a country like China, and not contact with students from China. Is it more difficult for USJ to compete with other universities, such as those of Hong Kong, by foreign students, outside China? The issue of recruitment of international students has become a priority for Macao universities. In the last two or three years, it has become evident that this internationalization is very important. What difficulty is there? There is the issue related to student visas, as these visas currently do not allow students to do any kind of work, denying them that minimum local subsistence mechanism to be able to meet expenses. Nor is it contemplated the possibility of, when the student concludes his formation, to be in the territory and find work. What all countries and regions that are competitive in higher education do, such as Singapore, Hong Kong or Australia, is to have incentive policies. Allow students to work part -time, for example. In Hong Kong when a degree ends, the student can stay in the territory up to a maximum of two years to find a job. This kind of measures do not yet exist in Macau, but I think the government is pondering this possibility. From the moment the decision was made that the internationalization of higher education was important, this must be accompanied with the corresponding measures. The current student visa is extremely limiting and does not encourage the coming to Macao to study, only allows coming. This issue was not as present as it is now, but now there is a strategic policy of internationalization. It is also a matter of survival for local universities. Yes. Perhaps there is no greater example of a catalyst for the diversification of Macau's economy than higher education. We have ten institutions, 60,000 students in about 700,000 inhabitants. This is the potential of internationalization, to foster diversification.
And also the research that comes out of higher education. The investigation, the dynamics of the work that is done. There are a number of vectors that higher education brings to a region or country, this happened to Portugal, for example, with the policy of doctoral scholarships for students from abroad, which completely changed the dynamics of higher education. Cape Verde developed thanks to the impact of higher education. Then we need to make the system more flexible in Macau. I don't know if it's a matter of having a holistic view of strategy. There may be an idea, but then it does not intervene in all the necessary dimensions to achieve a certain goal. But I am very optimistic. I believe this new student policy is a key step to be taken in Macau. The internationalization strategy followed by all these countries and regions I spoke, and were successful in capturing international students, was always the same. No need to invent much. First, one should increase the capacity and notoriety of universities, and then a policy of scholarships, which will enhance a student flow, creating a reference for the territory, so that studying there becomes a habit. After this flow of students for a few years, an image is already created and some scholarships can be removed, which students will continue to choose a particular territory to study in it. Australia has a huge higher education industry, for example, and I think that in Macau we just have to follow the same strategies. We do, at USJ, that a little. How, in concrete terms? We offer many scholarships, and in this sense the Diocese of Macao has helped us build this flow of international students that allow us to create this dynamic that we hope will be sustainable by itself in the future. I think the government is also doing this. There have always been scholarships in Macau, attributed mainly by the Macau Foundation, but this measure will be strengthened. Solving the student's visa issue, creating a scholarship incentive system for five to ten years, Macau will have a bright future as an international higher education destination. But we need to invest, continue, and it takes a few years. USJ created the “Macau Hub” platform, in partnership with the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center (CCCM) in 2023. At what stage is this project? This project has to do with our interest in developing a relationship dynamic of Lusophone countries centered in Lisbon in the area of ​​entrepreneurship, first. This cabinet we have at CCCM is not intended to offer training in Portugal, but we want to do something else. As we are positioned in the Great Bay and with Hengqin, where it is intended to activate a business ecosystem, we want to take advantage of the fact that we have relations with the Lusophone world to activate the access of the startups of Portugal, Brazil and Angola, above all, to the great bay and hengqin. We are trying to create a kind of incubator of transnational companies, in which we support the development of Lusophone businesses that want to settle in the large bay and also the reverse system. Strategically, for a university, it is absolutely fundamental to have a dynamic in the area of ​​entrepreneurship. Currently, more than half of our students do not want to go to the corporate world, but create their own businesses. Just as universities have to have employability solutions, they also have to have them for entrepreneurs, who are increasingly. So a university has to have a business incubator. My vision of the future for higher education goes around: a university, besides having a library and canteen, will also have its own business incubator. I would say that most students of management or economy courses dream of having their own business, especially in China. China is perhaps one of the most entrepreneurial countries in the world. The CCCM welcomes this initiative in Portugal, but we also work with the Portuguese Catholic University. And concrete results, already have it? We have a number of small initial projects that are starting now, and we also work with many business organizations. We have now negotiated a series of projects, and I think everything will develop very quickly, based on the manifestations of interest we have. We were in Angola in December and we have already aligned a series of initiatives, we also have projects with Brazil and Portugal.

item.title: Images about China populated New Show from Halftone
item.description: Halftone-Macao Photographic Association inaugurates this Friday a new exhibition dedicated to China's culture and visions. “The Spirit of China” is the name of the show that can be seen on the 3rd floor of The Parisian Macao, in Cotai, from 6.30 pm, being patent until May 11. This collective exhibition brings together the works of 17 photographers based in Macau, which exploit, through strong visual narratives, the evolution of Chinese identity and its contemporary meaning. Names such as João Palla, Sofia Mota, Sara Augusto or Francisco Ricarte, among others. Some are dedicated exclusively to photography, others just make it a hobby. The idea is to reveal this crossing ways of photographing. According to a statement from Halftone, which also publishes a photography magazine, “the show proposes a reflection on how fast urbanization and the emergence of megacities coexist with historical neighborhoods, such as religious rituals and old festivities dialogue with digital culture, and how new generations are redefining what it means to be Chinese in the 21st century”. “With the use of documentary, contemporary and conceptual photography, the works go through time and space-past, present and future imagined-offering deep visions about heritage, urban landmarks and new forms of visual expression,” he adds. Its own dynamic Halftone also points out, in the same note, that “more than a representation of Chinese legacy”, this exhibition “reveals identity as a living force - constantly shaped by social, dynamic diaspora and digital interconnectivity”. “The public is invited to reflect on the coexistence between the old and the new, and to get involved with the spirit of a nation in transformation,” is still mentioned. "The Spirit of China" shows a country that "has undergone an impressive transformation in recent decades, reconfiguring not only its urban horizons and architectural landscapes, but also the very essence of its cultural identity." “Given a rapid modernization and the advancement of technology, a new generation has been building a dynamic dialogue between tradition and innovation,” the note describes.

item.title: Japan | IWO JIMA VISIT IMPERIAL
item.description:
The visit of the Japanese emperors serves to mark the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II, in a territory that was the scene of one of the most bloody battles of the conflict
The emperors of Japan, Naruhito and Masako, yesterday arrived on the island of Iwo Jima, scenario of one of the most bloody battles of World War II, under the 80th anniversary celebrations of the end of the global conflict. This is the first time that the imperial couple has visited the remote island, now officially designated Ioto, located about 1,250 kilometers south of Tokyo, where they will pay tribute to the war memorials highlighted there. The Battle of Iwo Jima is considered one of the bloodiest battles of the Pacific World War Pacific campaign. During the five weeks that lasted, about 7,000 US soldiers and almost 22,000 Japanese soldiers were killed, among 80,000 soldiers who fought on this island of only 21 square kilometers. The island take, remote and strongly fortified, on March 26, 1945, was considered a fundamental step in advancing allied forces in the Pacific, in order to invade the main territory of the Japanese archipelago, although the strategic importance of the battle is still debated by the experts. The island was returned to Japanese sovereignty in 1968 and officially renamed Ioto in 2007, at the request of the area inhabitants, a name actually used by the former inhabitants. item.title: Lusophone exports to China fall more than 30% until February
item.description: Exports from Portuguese -speaking countries to China fell 30.7 percent in the first two months of 2025, compared to the same period last year. According to information from China's customs services, in January and February the Lusophone Block sold goods of $ 17 billion to the Chinese market. According to the data, gathered by the Forum for Economic and Commercial Cooperation between China and the Portuguese -speaking countries (Macao Forum), this is the lowest value for the first two months of a year since 2021, in the middle of COVID - 19 pandemic. The descent was due mainly to the largest Lusophone supplier in the Chinese market, Brazil, whose sales fell one third (33.4 percent) to $ 13.7 billion. In addition, also the second largest Chinese commercial partner in the Lusophone block, Angola, saw exports decrease 16.4 percent to $ 2.37 billion. Also the sales of goods from Portugal to China decreased by 13 percent to $ 444.4 million. On the contrary, the exports of Mozambique rose more than one third (34.4 percent) to $ 332.2 million. Equatorial Guinea exports to the Chinese market dropped 71.2 percent to $ 85.6 million, while Timor-Leste sales shred 98 percent. The exports of Sao Tome and Principe also fell 53.3 percent, although the country did not sell more than 1,000 dollars in goods. Already Cape Verde and Guinea-Bissau did not sell any merchandise to China in the first two months of 2025. On the other hand In the opposite direction, Chinese exports to Portuguese -speaking countries also reduced 9 percent to $ 12.2 billion. The data reveal that Brazil was the largest buyer in the Lusophone block, with imports from China to reach $ 10.3 billion, a drop of 7.8 percent in annual terms. Second on the list comes Portugal, which bought the goods of $ 932.4 million, less than 10.5 percent than in the same period as 2024. China registered a commercial deficit of $ 4.78 billion with the Lusophone Block in the first two months of 2025. In all, trade between Portuguese -speaking countries and China reached $ 29.2 billion, less 23.1 percent than in the same period last year.

item.title: EPM | Paulo Rangel guarantees increased financial support after 11 years of cuts
item.description:
On a lightning visit to Macao, Portugal's Foreign Minister argued that the position the country maintains in the European Union does not affect the relationship with China. During Paulo Rangel's visit, it was also announced that Sam Hou Fai should visit Portugal during the summer
He met with Sam Hou Fai, with counselors from the Portuguese communities, associative representatives, Portuguese educational institutions and entrepreneurs. Thus was the visit of Paulo Rangel, Minister of Foreign Affairs of Portugal, in the short visit to the MSAR, which took place on Friday. There are no passages in the Portuguese School of Macau (EPM) and the Consulate General of Portugal in the territory. In the late afternoon, Paulo Rangel also moved to Hong Kong to visit the exhibition “Lusas Stories”, dedicated to the Portuguese community of the territory, patent at the Hong Kong History Museum. In China, Paulo Rangel was present at the Boao Forum in Haião. In an interview with TDM, the minister assured that Portugal's relations with China remain good, denying that the country's position in the European Union's position (EU) can represent some kind of obstacle. "Anyone who thinks that Portugal's presence in the EU is harmful to Portugal's relationship with China, does not realize Portugal's relationship with China and does not realize the role of Portugal in the international picture. I realize that some people do not understand, but honestly we have to see it as more value. And this is seen like this," he said. One of the voices that criticized Portugal's position in relation to stories such as the issue of Huawei and Rede 5G was Amelia António, lawyer and president of the House of Portugal in Macau. “My expectation is not high. I would like you minister, after visiting China, to say something friendly, as relationships have been very loose. I would like to see this relationship resumed as usual and also that we were not as followers of the EU positions, so fiercely, because we have very special interests and we have a very large Portuguese community. It should not be lost sight of, ”he told Paulo Rangel to Macao. The EPM question In the interview given to TDM, Paulo Rangel also commented on the issue of EPM, stressing the points that were not on the agenda, namely the works of expansion of the facilities. "This question has not yet been addressed. There are, in fact, several issues that have to be detailed and resolved, and one or the other that have not yet been put on the table. We know that there is search for it, but and I am being totally transparent, it is a question that is not yet on the table." According to Lusa, Paulo Rangel also announced that the government increased financial support to the EPM, returning to the legally expected level after 11 years of cuts. "We just replaced the Portuguese contribution to the Portuguese School of Macao, which (…) had suffered a huge cut," Rangel said on Friday. The Portuguese State holds the majority (51 percent) of the capital of the EPM foundation, but since 2014 that Lisbon only contributed with 10 percent of school expenses, a decision taken under the Portuguese financial rescue program. EPM financing “is now at legal levels again and is the first time at the end of 11 years,” he said. Shortly thereafter, the chief of Portuguese diplomacy told reporters that "there was no reason, honestly, to have this cut and he remained." "We have increased five times this value [of EPM financing], so this is something that is highly significant from the commitment we have." "There are governments that really give importance to Macau and China and there are others who do not give, this is something that has to be said," lamented the minister, pointing his finger at the previous executive of the Socialist Party. The replacement of financing “is undoubtedly an important help” for EPM, which Rangel described as having a key role for Portugal in Macau. "We also have pleased ... that there have never been so many Portuguese students - and now I speak of students from the Chinese community - as there are today in multiple schools," added the leader. "It means that also the special administrative region [of Macau] has encouraged Portuguese teaching and knowledge of Portuguese, and this is something that can only bring good relations between the two sides," added Rangel. SAM in Portugal From the meeting with Sam Hou Fai, which also took place on Friday, some ideas and opinions on “bilateral exchange and cooperation in the judicial, economic-commercial, education, among others,” says an official note from the Social Communication Office. Sam Hou Fai led to the meeting topics such as “the most current development of the deepened cooperation zone between Guangdong and Macau in Henqing”, and remembered that “Paulo Rangel is the first foreign ministerial guardian he receives after the executive's head of the executive, a fact that reflects the good relations between Macao and Portugal with a longtime history”. The head of the executive also pointed out that after December 20, 1999, Macau, "with strong support from the central government, has insisted on maintaining the principle of" a country, two systems ", preserving the continental legal system, traditional culture and customs, as well as actively maintaining the connection and foster relations with Portugal." The ruler also said that "Macao has deepened the role of bridge and platform between China and Lusophone countries, continuously boosting the establishment of friendly relationships in the various areas of bilateral cooperation." Another novelty of this meeting was the information, advanced by Sam Hou Fai himself, which “expects to visit Portugal in the near future” without, however, a concrete date has been announced. Rangel announced that the chief executive of Macao is expected to visit Portugal "immediately before August or in September." "There is clearly here also an alignment of the priorities that is highly symbolic," said the diplomat, on the fringes of a meeting with the Portuguese community in Macau. Asked about the restrictions to Portuguese in accessing the resident status, Rangel said he spoke with Sam Hou Fai "on all the issues that are relevant to the relationship between Portugal and the MSAR." "But, as it is a dialogue that is underway, I have a duty to give the opportunity we can, with the questions that have been raised from one part and the other, now we have space and time to build solutions," he added. Rangel said that the "follow -up of dialogue" with Sam Hou Fai will take place at a meeting of the Portugal -Raem Joint Commission, "which will be organized in principle in the second semester here in Macao." Paulo Rangel also said, in an interview with TDM, that the visit of Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa, president of the Portuguese Republic, “will happen a little later”, precisely due to the marking of new elections in the country. Initially, the aim was that Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa came to Macao in June to commemorate Portugal, Camões and Portuguese communities. The visit should take place in the following months of summer, predicted Paulo Rangel. Encounters and mismatches Paulo Rangel also had a meeting with local associative representatives, including with the Portuguese communities counselor. Francisco Mannhão, president of the Macao Retirees, Reformed and Pensioners Association (Apomac), took the opportunity to talk about the bureaucracy that still exists in the relationship with the Caixa Geral de Retirement (CGA). "To dispatch a survival pension process takes six months and then the correspondence goes back and forth. Macao benches do not have Iban, and this, for example, delays the whole process. Whenever a process goes to CGA, they insist that they do not have the number of IBAN and NIF [Fiscal Identification Number], that most of the widows receiving survival pensions, do not have in Portugal." exemplified. Mannão also compliments to the Portuguese politician. "For a short time he was here, he showed concern. I liked the presence of the minister." In addition, Francisco Mannão stressed that “in a good time the Portuguese government appointed Alexandre Leitão to Consul”, also recalling the good work of the previous Portuguese consul, Vítor Sereno. "The consulate has never been as well functioned as now. The criticism made to our consul are unfair. There were our associates who told me to have been admired for making a marking and was attended the next day," he said. More bet on the language Another important point of Rangel's visit was the promise of the reinforcement of Mandarin teaching in Portugal. "With the Chinese authorities I made a point of saying that we will be very committed to teaching Chinese in Portugal." In the Chinese capital, Rangel met with Chinese counterpart, Wang Yi, before meeting with Chinese vice-minister, Ding Xuexiang, on Hailão Island, where the Boao Forum took place. "The situation today is much better than it was 20 years ago ... We have, in fact, a formation that we did not have at all," said Paulo Rangel. The formation of fluent people in Mandarin “is also decisive for our future”, but “it is not enough for the challenges we have ahead,” he warned. Lame

Yes to the electronic vote Also to Lusa several associative leaders defended the transition to electronic vote, stressing embarrassment in the current options for emigration. "With the advancement of technology and the possibility of implementing security systems that can ensure vote safety - which happens today through the provision of services in other areas of the government also - the conditions are created so that we can eventually evolve into a situation where it can obviously be a complement, but not a substitute," he noticed. In February, the Portuguese Parliament approved a resolution proposed by the PSD to test the electronic vote in emigration. Satellite city and pensions In a list that will lead the association by 2028, the motto is “we are elderly but energetic”, reads in the action program. One of the requests on the list to the government led by Sam Hou Fai is the increase in pensions, which is currently 3,740 patacas. "It would be good for the government of MSar to pay the pension monthly to the elderly, the pecuniary compensation and the old age, instead of having to wait every three months to receive the pension for the elderly, seven months to receive the pecuniary compensation and ten months to receive old age. Still, Mannão assures that being elderly in Macau is much easier than in Hong Kong. “Nowadays, in Macau, the elderly live quite well, because there are many social support attributed to this group of people. Sufficient resources Asked about the essential points to make Apomac a larger association, Francisco Mannhão says that “they have enough”, but lames the closure of the clinic where they were provided to the elderly health care. Jorge Fão, in turn, stressed that Apomac is also popular with non -partners, including from the Chinese community, to treat various issues, such as requests for subsidies or funeral -related paperwork. Still looking at the Action program, Apomac's list also aims to “organize more sightseeing tours to mainland China, making known its culture and success of the country”, as well as the promotion of “more coexistence, so that members join periodically”. Asked if many elderly from Macau want to pass the renovation in China one day, at a time when regional integration is increasingly a reality, Francisco Mannão admits yes, although many “prefer to stay in the territory, as they have their life rooted here, being used to the uses and customs of Macao”. item.title: Book | Mark O'Neill tells the history of Europeans in the early days of Hong Kong
item.description:
“Europeans in Hong Kong” is the 18th and new book by British writer and journalist Mark O'Neill, who lives in the neighboring region. At HM, he confesses that he began to write the history of the Irish, but the project eventually expanded. As such, it focused on the stories of Europeans who left their brand in Hong Kong, including Portuguese
Hong Kong, the city of banking, finance and commerce, a worldwide warehouse for centuries and a gateway to China. It has been the neighboring region throughout the time, since its institution, in 1841. Hong Kong has always been an international territory populated by Europeans of various nationalities, much more than the British who administered the territory until 1997. It was missing to tell its story, and British author and journalist Mark O'Neill, residing in Hong Kong since the late 1970s, now has it now with “European Europeans in Hong Kong], which even includes a chapter about the Portuguese. In another work that has just left the newsstands, the author confesses to HM who began to write the history of the Irish in Hong Kong, whose contribution to the "was huge" territory. This work was not published, being born later the idea of ​​doing something bigger. “I chose the figures that made the greatest contributions, especially at the religious level, or teachers, writers, great figures in the business world and those whose legacies still last,” he confessed. Mark O'Neill points out that the great contribution of Europeans in the neighboring region took place in the educational area, but not only. "The most lasting contribution was given by schools, universities, hospitals, homes of elderly, social assistance institutions and some companies. Although they are entities that are currently managed, largely, by people from Hong Kong, were founded and fed by Europeans." The author explains that the most impressive story associated with the legacy of the French arises on the cover of the book. "In the nineteenth century, the French nuns adopted tens of thousands of Chinese girls who had been abandoned and gave them a good life. Without them, girls would have died or worked as child labor, maids or prostitutes," he said. Another house Asked about the new perceptions that the book can bring to the general public, Mark O'Neill understands that he is today "familiar with the history of British in Hong Kong, but not with the history of continental Europe." Thus, the author says he hopes that "the book will help them understand their history, especially their contribution." In general terms, "in the early decades [of the Hong Kong Foundation], Europeans were, above all, business men and missionaries, both Catholic and Protestants." Then the region grew “as a great Asian city and, from the 1950s, the community expanded.” "Currently, we have architects, engineers, musicians, teachers, restaurant owners, doctors, lawyers, art and people experts in all the domains of life," said the author. Another prominent figure in “Europeans in Hong Kong” is the Jesuit Hungarian Father Laszlo Ladany, considered the “China's greatest observer in the world for thirty years”, and Anders Nelson, “Swedish singer and long-standing resident in Hong Kong, well known to local inhabitants”, describes the introduction of the work. “Most people think that Hong Kong was built by the Chinese during their 150 years of British dominance, which is not entirely accurate. As the reader will discover, many of the schools, social assistance institutions, buildings and companies in the city were founded and managed by people from Europe (defined here as 'east of calais'). They forced it, ”is described in the same introduction. Mark O'Neill also describes that the Hong Kong cemeteries contain traces of this presence, as "Europeans have enjoyed the city and their people more than their homeland." The European presence increased in the neighboring region from 1949, when the People's Republic of China is founded, as "the new Chinese government closed the doors to foreigners, with the exception of a small number of people from other socialist countries." Thus, "eager to remain in China and in the Chinese world, many Europeans have moved from mainland China to Hong Kong," he is mentioned. The Macaense Legacy The fourth chapter is entirely dedicated to the Portuguese and Macaense Hong Kong community, regarded as a “pillar of society” for many years. “For 150 years, the Portuguese were, after the British, the largest non-Chinese community in Hong Kong,” reads the work, which draws the profile of five personalities and describes two social clubs where the community was. Regarding the personalities, the example of José Pedro Braga, the first Portuguese to be part of the Legislative Council, between 1927 and 1937; Sir Roger Lobo, member of the Executive Council between 1967 and 1985; and Commander Arnaldo de Oliveira Sales, first president of the urban council between 1973 and 1981. "The Portuguese played a key role in the government, in banks, the liberal professions and the commercial companies. They lived here for many generations. Most of the expatriates were only the time of their mission; when they renovated, departed and returned to Britain or another country in Europe. book. Regarding the origin of this community, it is described as a “mixed race”, or macanese, but also Portuguese with Asian origins. “Its history dates back to hundreds of years, in the early days of Portuguese trade and exploitation. In the 16th century, Portugal established commercial warehouses and religious missions in Goa, Malaca, Macau and Nagasaki. The Portuguese settlers married local women, creating a mixed root population in India, Malaysia, China and Japan. In 1639, the Japanese government expelled all foreigners and foreigners and isolated the country from the rest of the world. ” Macao emerges closely linked to this community, as it became, in the mid-16th century, “the basis of Portugal in East Asia” after the Dutch blocked Goa and won Malacca. "The Macanese began to form as a cohesive community-sharing ties with Portugal, the Catholic religion, a common language and kitchen and a feeling of distinction from the Portuguese colonials and their Chinese neighbors. They were the only people in Macao who spoke Portuguese and Cantonese, giving them a role of intermediaries essential for the proper functioning of government and business," he is explained. The fact that “the Hong Kong foundation has devastated the economy of Macao” made many macanese began to move from weapons and luggage to a much more brightly saving zone. After all, "just 66 kilometers away [Hong Kong] was the best deep water port in southern China within laws, administration and military protection in the largest empire in the world."

The Boa Goveal Forum for Asia 2025 ends on Friday and has as its theme “Asia in the world in transformation: Towards a shared future” [Asia in the Changing World: Tows a Shared Future], and, according to a statement released by the chief executive's office, focuses on four essential areas, one of them “rebuilding confidence and promoting cooperation in a rapid transformation world”. Objectives are followed by "encouraging growth and rebalanced globalization for inclusive development" or "modeling the future and rapidly implementing the objectives of sustainable development to respond more effectively to global challenges." In turn, the fourth objective concerns a very current area: Artificial Intelligence (AI). It is thus intended to “explore potentialities and intensify AI's application and governance for development motivated by innovation”. According to the People's Daily Journal, this year are expected for more than two thousand participants from 60 countries and regions, being held 50 forums, or discussion groups, around the above objectives. 1,140 journalists are expected to coverage the event. The forecasts of a forum The main conferences of the Boao Forum include discussions about the Chinese and World Economy, namely in "High-Level dialogue: China's reform and economic predictions" and "construction of an open world economy: challenges and solutions." Following is “Improvement of the construction of digital capacity & conforming the gap between digital”, as well as “unlock the great potential of regional free trade agreements”. Among the remaining panels are also conversations about the potential of AI in "AI: how to ensure a balance between application and governance." Countries will also address the issue of global governance in the relationship with the United Nations (UN), in "high-level dialogue: global governance after the UN summit of the future." But the discussion forums start with some predictions made in the report released in the context of the Boao Forum, entitled "Asian Economic Outlook and Integration Progress". One of the forecasts is that the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of the Asian continent should grow 4.5 percent this year, reported Xinhua. "Despite growing global economic uncertainty, Asia remains a key growth engine for the world economy," the report says. In addition, in terms of parity of purchasing power, the Asia GDP ratio, within the world total, is expected to increase from a registration of 48.1 percent last year to 48.6 percent this year. In turn, the report describes that the general situation of employment and wages “is improving in Asia”, with an unemployment rate of 4.39 percent for this year, less than the global rate of 4.96 percent. The Asian Economic Outlook and Integration Progress also highlights foreign investments in Asia, describing that China and Asean-Association of Southeast Asia nations "are the most appealing economies in Asia." In addition, it refers that the dependence on the internal and external foreign direct and external investment of Asian economies in the region itself reached 49.15 percent by 2023. From the point of view of the bidirectional dependence of IDE in Asia, China continued to be the most dependent economy of the Asian IDE flows, followed by Indonesia, with its dependence rates over 80 percent and 75 percent, respectively. The report also pointed out that China remains the center of global production value chains, and since 2017, global trade in intermediate goods has been more dependent on China than in North America. In 2023, China's global dependence on intermediate goods was 16 percent compared to 15 percent to North America. The commercial friction caused by the United States in 2018 did not raise their position in the global value chains of the transforming industry, the report added. Thus, the advance of Asia is also described in the level of emerging green technologies, since this is "driven by strong industrial capabilities and political support." Thus, the continent seems to be positioning itself "as a potential leader in advanced materials related to batteries or production of biodegradable plastics." China, Japan, and the Republic of Korea dominate the Lithium Battery Battery Technology Global Supply Chain, a factor considered crucial for the electrification of transport, the report underlines. However, China is at the forefront of the expanding green hydrogen industry in Asia, being the region responsible for almost 70 percent of the worldwide capacity of hydrogen electrolisters, also reveals the same report. An ecological island According to an Xinhua report, Haião Island, which welcomes the Boao Forum, is “a pioneer in development with low carbon emissions”, namely the use of photovoltaic energy. "On Dongyu Island, in Hainan province, southern China, the almost null carbon emissions demonstration zone is redefining harmony between humanity and nature-remodeling modern life through the integration of cutting-edge technology with sustainable development," he describes. But there are more technological news, such as the use of "a simple QR code that unlocks a coffee carbon emissions experience, and where a robotic arm prepares coffee using clean energy." There is also the bet on recycling, as "an advanced recycling cube separates the materials, converting them into" carbon points ", which can be changed to ecological awards." The area that welcomes the Boao Forum has a total area of ​​190 hectares, where a bet on “three key strategies” was made, namely the “renewal of ecological buildings, use of renewable energy and ecological transport”. The renewal of the zone for more sustainable bets will have begun in 2022, being proof of “how technological innovation and urban renewal can shape a future with low carbon emissions, paving the way for sustainable development, particularly in the tropical regions of the world,” says Xinhua. Also according to the same report, "one of the main strengths of the area lies in energy production capacity", currently producing "about 32 million kWh of green electricity, almost double its search for 17 million kWh". In turn, "surplus energy is introduced into the network, contributing to an annual savings of 7 720 tons of negative carbon resources," he said to Xinhua Ouyang Qinglun, deputy director of the Cosco Shipping Boao Co. item.title: History | Lara Reis, Professor of Macao High School, remembered in Lisbon
item.description:
The former teacher of the Macao High School Fernando Lara Reis was remembered in the “Spring Conferences”, from the Macao Scientific and Cultural Center, by historian Celina Veiga de Oliveira. A native of Leiria, Lara Reis fought in the 1st World War and lived on Avenida da República, in the villa that today houses the Macau Red Cross house
Fernando Lara Reis was born in 1892 and died in 1950. Throughout a life filled with historical events and testimonies, the natural man of Leiria was a military man and a teacher at Macao High School, eventually making the territory his home. Lara Reis's life was recently remembered at the “Spring Conferences” of the Macao Scientific and Cultural Center (CCCM) by historian Celina Veiga de Oliveira, herself to her former teacher in the territory. At the session, the historian, who won the 2024 Macao International Institute Identity Award (IIM), recalled the “teacher, meritorious, driving of the arts”, and owner of “unusual knowledge”. “He was a native of Leiria and lived in Macao until his death. He attended Leiria High School, the Military College, then joined the Army School. In World War I was in Elvas, and then left to Angola in 1915 when he faced the German threat over Portuguese colonies in Africa. Observer-Aviator. ” Lara Reis was never a pilot as she wanted, having dedicated much of her life to teaching and Macao. “In 1919, Lara Reis went to Macao High School. He took a long circum-gap trip, leaving Portugal from Lisbon, going to the United States of America, crossed the entire territory and then went to Japan, down to Hong Kong and even Macau. He was a teacher in Macao, drawing, handicrafts and gymnastics until the end of his life,” said Celina Veiga de Oliveira. The historian took to the session some written testimonies left by other Macao figures who wrote about Lara Reis, namely Monsignor Manuel Teixeira in the book “Macao Lyceu”. He said he never found "no teacher who had served the High School with greater dedication." “He was a rigorous methodical teacher, whose military formation was certainly not oblivious to these characteristics. What was truly standing out was his artistic vein, because Lara Reis was always concerned with ascertaining the aesthetic meaning of the students and opening their mental horizons. This at the time when Macau was a small town. that he organized and also exhibitions by Portuguese and foreign artists he sponsored, ”he recalled. Celina Veiga de Oliveira also highlighted the words left by the writer Henrique de Senna Fernandes in an interview on "one of the greatest qualities of Lara Reis", which "besides rigor and discipline, was the consideration by the students, not distinguishing rich from the poor." Professor Lara Reis was "a party prosecutor who served to obtain tuition fees for needy students," and "he is due to the initiative of the creation of the High School Association, of which he was the first president." This association organized in the former canhydrome “sports parties of the end of the year when students performed the most difficult exercises”. Work done in Macau The historian also highlighted “another aspect of dedication to territory” by Lara Reis. The Leiriense "participated in the First World War and this led him to interest all those who were incorporated into this conflict, having founded the League of the Great War fighters and had built in the cemetery of St. Miguel Archangel the monument where the bodies of combatants rest." Moreover, "another facet of his personality was a taste for travel, because he had no family and thus left for the world." "I visited museums, art schools and photographed everything I saw, having created a estate with 32 volumes that is now a heritage of Leiria." Celina Veiga de Oliveira did not forget the old “Sol Pente” villa, located in the middle-leaf zone, namely the Avenida da República, which was the house of Lara Reis, later donated to the Santa Casa da Misericórdia de Macao to “an anti-cancer clinic that was the first institution of the genre in the Portuguese colonial space”. Today this villa serves as a house to the Red Cross of Macao, and on its walls you can find a stone with the following message: “In this building legacy by the Rotary Fernando Reis to the Santa Casa da Misericórdia de Macao, it was installed at the initiative of the Rotary Club of Macao the first anti-cancer fighting center on April 15, 1951.” “Change of Ares” When Fernando Lara Reis goes to Macao, political times are troubled, with the political agitation to be lived in China after the fall of the Empire and the Republican Revolution of 1911. "In the 1920s the nationalist shock waves lived in the Canton, which sometimes haunted the Portuguese enclave quiet, but never moved with everyday life. The Portuguese administration guaranteed a standard appearance, and the parties at Christmas, Chinese New Year, the religious festivities of the Catholic community and the Chinese population were habitual." Celina Veiga de Oliveira recalled that in the late 1920s, Lara Reis decided to transfer to Goa, a trip that would only accentuate her belonging to Macau. “In the late 1920s, he felt he was time to change his air and asked to be transferred to the Afonso de Albuquerque High School in Pangim, and was there between 1941 and 1945, taking the opportunity to know India, and met the whole country. Instead, with a graceful and already sick license, choosing Macau to be his last address, ”he recalled. Celina Veiga de Oliveira recordou também as palavras de Orlando Cardoso, que no artigo “Macau e o Oriente na vida de Lara Reis” falou do homem que se deslumbrou com Macau “a partir do momento em que, às 8 horas da noite de 23 de Outubro de 1919, avistou pela primeira vez o Farol da Guia, um pouco antes de se instalar no ‘New Macao Hotel’ e sorver de sentidos atentos os sons, os cheiros e as luzes desta porta of an immeasurable and fantastic Asia that he would describe to exhaustion. ” These Lara Reis testimonies are “in a remarkable set of travel books that lay virtually unexplored in all their research potentialities on the shelves of the Leiria District Archive”, and were investigated by Orlando Cardoso himself. In the same article, this one refers to a text from the newspaper “News of Macau” of January 17, 1950, about Lara Kings: “The Auster and Worsen Teacher; the tenacious and thorough tourist; the military who fought and consecrated the memory of those who fell in the field of struggle; the honest and firm friend; the lovely and humorous companion; social celibate that, despite this, did not disdain any opportunity to undo its gallants, always kind and inconsequential to any palm with a face that in the goto ”. Given the few studies that exist about Lara Reis and the estate he left, Celina Veiga de Oliveira left a suggestion: "May the CCCM get the detailed index of the Leiria Archive, so that the research is possible for any interested researchers."

item.title: Public Hiring | New regime “is on the good way,” says lawyer
item.description:
Marco Caldeira, a lawyer and auxiliary teacher at the University of Lisbon Faculty of Law, argues that the proposed public hiring law, under analysis in the specialty in Hemiciclo, is “on the good way” regarding the attempt to “promote transparency and competition and bet on digitization”. The theme was discussed last week at the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center
The proposal of public hiring, currently under analysis in the specialty in the First Permanent Commission of the Legislative Assembly (AL), was one of the topics addressed in the “Spring Conferences”, at the Macao Scientific and Cultural Center (CCCM) last week. The author of the lecture, the lawyer and teacher Marco Caldeira, made praise for the diploma for his attempt to reform and innovation in many respects. "Although not perfect, the bill under discussion is justified by the need to update legislation that was approved four decades ago. It is a proposal that seems to point in the good way, with an effort to codify the regime, promote transparency and competition and bet on digitization," said the professor at the University of Lisbon Law School (FDUL) to HM. In addition, Marco Caldeira understands that the diploma, and the content proposed by the government, aims to "follow what are good practices adopted in Europe and the West in general." "It is also very commendable that the proposal was prepared following a serious and participated procedure of public consultation, which gave the opportunity to economic operators and contracting entities to identify deficiencies in current legislation and make suggestions," added Marco Caldeira. At the CCCM session, the FDUL professor also pointed out that the concern [demonstrated, in the diploma] with the competition and transparency of the procedures ”, as well as“ the focus on training in the use of databases, as well as the focus on centralization ”. The teacher also understood that, in this bill, the Portuguese regime "can help, because the practice followed in Portugal, and legislative evolutions, have useful teachings that, with proper adaptations, can be transposed to Macao." Positive points In the presentation at CCCM, Marco Caldeira highlighted several positive aspects of the current law proposal, namely “the express determination of inapplicability to certain contracts”, or the fact that “fundamental principles of public hiring” are established. It is also required with the new law “qualifications to candidates and competitors” of public tenders, and there is also “the clarification and standardization of the types of public hiring procedures”. Thus, a “centralized hiring regime” is created, as well as regulating “award criteria” in competitions, and the creation of an exclusive website for the public hiring area is also foreseen. Marco Caldeira also drew attention to the real need of this diploma, as public hiring was legislated with various diplomas, including two decrees of 1984 and 1985, which established, respectively, the expenditure regime with works and service acquisitions, and the process of acquisition of goods and services. Such diplomas were “undone of reality” of Macao, even though the 1984 decree was reviewed in 2021, the teacher considered. Marco Caldeira also considered that the process of reviewing this diploma has been “lengthy”, as the public consultation took place between November 6, 2018 and January 4, 2019, and a later report was prepared, but the truth is that the proposal has been under analysis since December 2023, having been voted generally on January 11 last year. What has to change In the same session, the causal and university professor also highlighted the points already addressed by the first Standing Commission of AL regarding the necessary changes to legislate in the area of ​​public hiring. It was imposed “expressly consecrating fundamental legal principles, such as economy, efficiency and effectiveness, as well as publicity and transparency”, and there is also “a lack of regulation of public hiring policies”. There was also the “need to promote transparency in public hiring procedures” and ensure “greater protection of loyal competition”. There was also “lack of rigorous and explicit regulation on the composition and operation of the proposals evaluation committees” submitted to a public tender, and there is “lack of explicit demands on the qualifications and capabilities of candidates and competitors in hiring procedures”. Other gaps point to “insufficient regulation and transparency in the evaluation and adjudication procedures”, or “lack of explicit regulation on proposals presentation with an abnormally low price”. It was still necessary to “improve the sanctioning and inspection regime”, as well as bet on “regulation that promotes the development of electronic hiring”. Says the executive Looking at the justification of the law proposal, submitted by the Executive to AL, it is read that one of the great reasons for his presentation was even the legislative dispersion that was verified and the misfit over the current reality. "The nuclear part of these diplomas was prepared in the mid-1980s, and has been in force for over 30 years. A significant part of the provisions of other legal diplomas already has an obvious divergence regarding the needs of Macao's current socioeconomic development, the efficiency of public administration management and the reinforcement of transparency and supervision," he reads. According to the executive, "given that public hiring involves the use of the public purse, it is essential to review these regimes in order to meet the needs of the society of our day." Thus, in this law proposal, “the process and regime of expenses and acquisitions of goods and services” are regulated, with some provisions of a 1999 law, as “the provisions related to the public works contract regime have a high degree of specialization and are still effective”. It is intended, with the new law of public hiring, to “guarantee justice, impartiality in the evaluation of proposals”, defining “expressly aid criteria and rigorously determining the rules of conduct of workers and members of the opening and evaluation of proposals” subjected to contest, so that “excerpt their functions impartially and entirely”. Thus, it is foreseen that “contracting entities must adequately publicize the informative elements related to public hiring procedures”. They are “those related to the public tender, the clarifications provided, the rectification of documents, the extension of the deadline for the presentation of proposals, the causes for non -adjudication, the decision to annul the procedure and the award decision”. In order to guarantee loyal competition, the government wants to ensure that all entities interested in participating in a competition have “the broader access” to all procedures, prohibiting “all acts, agreements or practices that can prevent, false or restrict competition”. Moreover, there is the “principle of impartiality”, which determines that “the program of procedures, book of charges or other documents, made by the contracting party, cannot contain any clause designed to favor or harm a particular interested party”.

item.title: Road Works | Au Kam San criticizes administration
item.description: Former Deputy Au Kam San criticizes the bureaucracy of the working group for the optimization of the Coordination of Road Works, launched by the Chief Executive. In a Facebook publication, Au Kam San understands that the creation of this public organism will not solve the problem of road works, having described that, despite this new group being led by the secretary for transport and public works, Raymond Tam, maintains the same ideas as the previous executive. In addition, the former deputy recalled the creation of another similar entity, the road works supervision group. "The joke that can be associated with this bureaucratic system is that if a group cannot do a job well, there will be another. If this work remains not done, there will always be another group and added service," he wrote. Au Kam San concluded that the problem of road works has existed since the establishment of MSAR, so it does not believe that it can be resolved through “improvements” and “coordination” with working groups. However, the second meeting of the working group was held yesterday to optimize the Coordination of Road Works, and Raymond also said, according to an official note, that “the government will require the promoter to reserve the spaces for the installation of channeling during the execution of the works, with a view to reducing the possibility of repeated excavations on public roads”. "Instructions for members of the working group and channeling companies were given to reduce the deadline for execution of works and apply more technology in order to minimize the impact on residents and retailers."

item.title: Tobacco | Residents want clarification of smokers zones
item.description: The General Union of Macao Residents Associations (Ugamm) argues that the government should more visibly demarcate the zones for smokers, removing them from the areas of the highest affluence of tourists. The position was taken by Che Mei Leng, vice president of Ugamm, in statements to the newspaper Exmooo. In a reaction to government plans to create a smoking zone near the ruins of Sao Paulo, Che indicates that it is necessary to keep in mind that smoke tends to spread and therefore should be avoided by affecting the other tourists, residents and traders of the zone. The official asks the area to be created far from the large concentrations of visitors. However, residents' deputy also recognizes that it is natural that smokers do not want the area to be far away from the main attractions. For this reason, Che Mei Leng considers that the government has to find a balance between the benefits for the residents of the zone and the interests of smokers. Che Mei Leng also suggested that a transitional period be implemented before punishments are applied so that tourists can be well informed about the consequences of their acts. At the same time, Che called the government to promote the dissemination of the measure on social networks.

item.title: Economic Housing | Permanent candidacy is again removed
item.description:
With attention focused on competitions for economic housing launched and 2019, 2021 and 2023, the Housing Institute removes the hypothesis allow permanent candidates. Regarding the five suspended housing projects in zone A of the new landfills, the government remains without construction plans
The Housing Institute (IH) is concentrated “in the work of appreciation and attribution of applications to Economic Housing of 2019, 2021 and 2023”. As such, it is not being weighted, in the short term, the permanent candidacy for economic housing, since it is necessary to comprehensively consider social changes and other factors, ”said the president of IH, iam Leng Leng, in response to a written interpellation of Nick Law. The deputy linked to the community of Fujian has insisted on the reform of housing policies, in particular in his flexibility. Nick Law stressed that there is no mechanism in the law that allows the exchange of housing fractions, a situation that penalizes individual candidates who cannot change their home even if over the contest marry or have children. Also on the possibility of changing home, I were Leng Leng has not advanced a concrete position, merely answering that the government will optimize housing policies and that it has launched a study on the viability of the economic housing exchange regime. The deputy asked when the study would be completed and if his results will be released, but the president of IH did not respond. Good zone A year ago, the then secretary for transport and public works, Raimundo do Rosario, revealed in the Legislative Assembly that the government would suspend the construction of six residential economic housing complexes in zone A of new landfills, which would add 5,700 apartments to the city's housing park. It should be noted that Raimundo do Rosario revealed the suspension in response to an oral interpellation of Nick Law. A year later, the deputy re -interrogated the government on construction and development projects. The president of the HI replied that, "taking into account the situation of candidacies for economic housing verified in the last two contests, the Government of MSAR, after evaluation, decided to suspend the development of economic housing projects in lots A13, B13, B14, B15 and B16, and there is no new plans for now."

item.title: Science Center | Subsidies cover losses of 141 million
item.description: Last year, the Macao Science Center presented operational losses of 141 million Patacas, which had to be covered by government subsidies. The data are contained in the latest results of the company's Mok Ian Ian -managed company results and detained 100 percent by MSAR. According to the figures presented, the operations of the Science Center generated losses of 141.0 million patacas. This number indicates losses above those registered in the previous year, which had been 121.8 million patacas. In operational terms, the Science Center registered 16.1 million patacas in revenues, which were added 1.4 million generated with capital interest, and 3.2 million classified as other revenues. At the same time, the expenses were 161.8 million Patacas, more 16 million than 2023, when they had been 145.8 million patacas. The main expenses were made with personnel costs, in the amount of 64.5 million patacas. Mok Ian Ian, as president of the institution, has an annual salary of nearly 1.6 million patacas. The second largest expense arises classified as “depreciation and amortization” in the amount of 50.5 million patacas. The third largest expense was due to advertising, in the amount of 9.2 million. In turn, the Government delivered subsidies of 141 million Patacas, including operations allowance, in the amount of 90.5 million patacas, allowance for acquisition of goods, 39.2 million patacas, and subsidy for special projects, worth 11.3 million patacas. By 2023, the climbed had been 121 million patacas, a difference of 20 million patacas.

item.title: National Security | Government wants to review laws on associations
item.description:
The SAM Hou Fai Executive intends to support the development of patriotic associations and review the laws that regulate associative management depending on the requirements inherent in national security. The reforms will follow “the important leading spirit of President XI Jinping”
The government will “review and optimize” the laws that regulate associations, in order to improve management and “guide its construction”, “depending on the requirements inherent to the general perspective of national security and the real needs for the social development of Macao”. The commitment to update the legislation related to associative life in Macao to safeguard national security was assumed by the Director of Administration and Public Function (SAFP), NG Wai Han, in response to a written interpelation of Chan U law. The intention of the Executive of Sam Hou Fai is the promotion of patriotic associativism as an essential pillar of grassroots governance. "The present mandate of the government will support the growing development of associations that love the homeland and Macao in grassroots governance, improve the network of community work, consolidate and expand the adhesion of residents," and "expand public services provided by the Government of Raem to the base social layer." Ng Wai Han also adds that the Executive intends to “coordinate the participation of associations that love the homeland and Macau in community construction and help them to enhance their contributions in the deepened cooperation zone between Guangdong and Macau in Hengqin”. Spirit of love The SAFP Director also assured that the government intends to “discuss the establishment of the criteria for the quality of social services and the creation of an examination and evaluation system”. At the interpetement, the deputy linked Federation of Macao Workers' Associations highlighted the importance of national governance at national level. "According to the statements of President Xi Jinping, a country is strong when its bases are strong and the world is safe when its bases are safe." Given this line of thought, the SAFP director ensures that "the present mandate of the government will expedit the important leading spirit of President XI Jinping, attributing special importance to communication and cooperation with associations that love the homeland and Macao."

item.title: Employment | Criticized bet on leavers from outside without experience
item.description:
Deputy Ron Lam accuses the government from having diverted the political intention of allowing local companies to hire non-residents with international experience and success, and instead be issuing residence permitted to young people without curriculum.
Legislator Ron Lam attacked the government's policy of allowing imports as “talents” of non -residents with academic education, but without any professional experience. Criticism arises in a written interpellation, where the member of the Legislative Assembly indicates that politics is inconsistent, since one is through a phase in which the unemployment of newly educated is becoming worse and worse. In the document released yesterday, Lam requires the government to end with the new status to authorize the residence of newly graduates with high notes, but without any professional experience. From the perspective of the deputy, these permits of setting residence in Macao contradicts the policies presented by the government, and which were approved in the Legislative Assembly, which aimed to import qualified labor from abroad extremely successful professionally in their areas of activity. While hiring abroad, the deputy indicates that young licenses cross a very complicated phase of entry into the labor market, and that people from Macao who have graduated abroad also find a job market with many challenges, with difficulties to find a long -term job. In this context, the deputy asks the Executive whether the regime will eliminate the hiring of non-residents without professional experience. The reality of numbers Regarding the problem of unemployment among the younger ones, the deputy cites last year's official statistics to indicate that 47.1 percent of local unemployed were at least one degree. And among the unemployed with training in higher education, 28.1 percent was between 25 and 34 years old. "The numbers show that compared to 2019, the situation of unemployment is more serious. Many young people and middle-aged people who have academic education at higher education have told us that it is increasingly difficult to find a job and that companies only want non-resident workers," Ron Lam describes. The deputy also writes that the various employment fairs organized by the Directorate of Services for Laboral Affairs offer little attractive jobs, and that in many cases job vacancies are “false”, not leading to hiring. Lam also criticizes the way unemployment statistics are compiled, indicating that there are discrepancies between the different published data, which in theory should be similar. The deputy asks the government to correct this problem as soon as possible to be able to take employment measures according to the reality of the local market.

item.title: Hong Kong International Academy Against Corruption (II)
item.description: Last week, we debated the Independent Commission Against Corruption of Hong Kong (HKICAC) (Hong Kong Against Corruption Committee) and Hong Kong International Academy Against Corruption (HKIAAC) (HGO KONG ACADEMY AGAINST CORRUPTION) and we introduced their origins succinctly. Macao Commissioner against Corruption, (CCAC). In 1975, during the Portuguese administration of Macao, the fight against corruption was carried out by the Judicial Police. In 1992, the then government of Macao created the High Commissioner against corruption and administrative illegality. Referring to Hong Kong's experience, which had become one of the most impollowing places in the world, when writing Macau's Basic Law, it was clearly stipulated that CCAC would have to be created. The CCAC website underlines the committed work it develops to review the law and strengthen the fight against corruption. One of the most illustrative cases is that of Man Long: “Investigating the case of corruption A to Man Long began in 2005, when during the investigation of a corruption case based on information available in the meantime, CCAC found that the then secretary for transport and public works was involved in suspicion of abuse of power. He will have accepted bribes of large construction entrepreneurs and the winners of major government works are indicated.” (In April 2007, the first phase of the inquiry against Man Long was completed. It was found that, during the time of the secretary, his heritage reached a total of 800 million patacas, ie, 57 times higher than the remuneration of the position. Objects. On January 30, Tui ordered Man Long for 57 crimes of passive corruption, whitening, abuse of power and others, to the prison penalty of 27 years and the payment of compensation of 240,000 Patacas to the Government of the Government, being declared in favor of the government all assets from illicit acts.). This shows that CCAC has achieved extraordinary results in its work to combat corruption. In 2006, the International Association of Anti-Corruption Authorities (Iaaca) was created in Beijing. It is the first international anti-corruption organization in the world with agencies from various member countries. It aims to actively promote the “United Nations Convention against Corruption” and reinforce international cooperation between counterparts from various countries. Cao Jianming, Attorney General of China's Supreme Popular Attorney's Office, was elected president of IAACA twice, on November 5, 2010 and November 24, 2013. The mandate of the IAACA President is three years. On January 5, 2022, the Commission Commission Commission against Hong Kong Corruption, Ba Yunliu, was elected as a new president. Later, Ba Yunliu retired. On September 1, 2023, Hu Yingming assumed the position of president of IAACA. IAACA has a “Federation Secretariat”, created by HKICAC on January 6, 2022 to support the HKICAC Commissioner in the exercise of his duties as president of IAACA. The main responsibility of the Federation Secretariat is to support or organize activities. HKIAAC is affiliated with the HKICAC International Cooperation and Institutional Affairs Division and performs part of the federation secretariat's duties.
